bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John R. Bullard, June 18, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Bullard for the autographed photographs. He describes the unveiling, performed by his daughter, of the Walter Reed painting. He includes the names of dignitaries in attendance. Kissinger suffered a major stroke after the unveiling.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John R. Bullard, June 18, 1941
div1.p:
I do appreciate your autographing your pictures and returning
them to me. Will you please remind me again in what year each of these
pictures was taken? I believe you told me that the photograph of you
all dressed up so nattily was in the year 1901. I don't quite remember
when the rowing photograph was taken.

Enclosed you will find a talk I gave during the week of the
American Medical Association meetings in Cleveland. The painting was
not quite finished but it is really very nice and was unveiled by Walter
Reed's daughter. Kissinger was there and most regretably had a very
severe stroke thirty-six hours later, just after he returned home. He
is unconscious much of the time, paralyzed on the right side and for
a while was not expected to live but now seems to be at least holding
his own. I don't know whether that is a blessing or not.

The audience at the time of the unveiling was small but very
select and included the Mayor of Cleveland, the President and President-
elect of the American Medical Association, deans of some medical schools,
representatives from certain art institutions, as well as Miss Reed, the
artist, Mr. Kissinger and myself. I have been so Peripatetic that I
still haven't written out adequately my notes on your own story. I will
try to do this as soon as I possibly can in the next few weeks, and get
it to you for your corrections and amendation.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
Mr. John R. Bullard
P. O. Box 59
St. Augustine, Florida
